thread.section_title: North Texas Mean Green News - Sports News for Dallas, Texas
thread.title: Winless UNT welcomes FCS foe; 'it's not a lost season by any means'
thread.title_full: Winless UNT welcomes FCS foe; 'it's not a lost season by any means' | Dallas Morning News

author: Brett Vito
title: Winless UNT welcomes FCS foe; 'it's not a lost season by any means'
text:
DENTON -- Dan McCarney attributes the success North Texas enjoyed during the high points of his tenure as the Mean Green's coach to a simple philosophy.
"When we built this program, we tried to establish a DNA of being unselfish, being physical, outhitting our opponent, not making excuses and fighting for our brothers," McCarney said. "I am seeing some of that, but not enough."
The search for that complete effort will continue Saturday when the Mean Green take on Portland State in what looks like one of UNT's best chances to turn its fortunes.
The Mean Green have already lost their first four games and will look to break though on homecoming against an opponent from the Football Championship Subdivision, a step down from the Football Bowl Subdivision, where UNT competes.
UNT is paying a hefty $425,000 fee to the Vikings to visit Apogee Stadium, which is just another reason the game looms large for the Mean Green.
"Starting 0-4 is not what we drew up in the offseason or how we thought we would start, but it's not a lost season by any means to any of us as players and coaches," UNT quarterback Andrew McNulty said. "We have a lot of things in front of us that are still attainable."
The chances of UNT reaching any of those goals, including the quickly fading one to win six games and become bowl-eligible, will be one step closer to being out of reach if the Mean Green can't come through today.
Unfortunately for UNT, its game against Portland State isn't the seemingly safe bet it appeared to be at the beginning of the season.
The Vikings pulled off a stunner when they beat Washington State in their opener and have rolled to a 3-1 record.
"Portland State is an excellent football team," McCarney said. "[Coach] Bruce Barnum has done a heck of a job. They have beaten a Pac-12 team in Washington State, and it wasn't a fluke. They outplayed them."
The question now is if UNT can find the form and drive that McCarney expects and win its first game. The Mean Green haven't really been close in any of their four losses while being outscored by an average of 45-17.
"We have to get more guys involved and show the talent that we have on offense," UNT wide receiver Carlos Harris said.
Harris has 27 of UNT's 66 receptions. The Mean Green have shown better balance in the running game with Antoinnne Jimmerson and Jeffrey Wilson carrying most of the load.
Jimmerson has 215 rushing yards in four games, while Wilson has quickly racked up 211 in two games since returning from a broken hand.
UNT has to hope that pair can help the Mean Green improve their time of possession from a dismal 25:07 a game and help the defense in the process.
"We have to make the plays we can make," UNT linebacker Calvin Minor said. "We are capable."
